Robert Gabriel - Web Development Year 4
Brienne Lloyd-Evans - Visual Communications Year 3
Peter Bohane - Visual Communications Year 3

item.title: Research : Survey Writing
item.dc:creator: robertgabriel2015
item.content:encoded:
Just a quick post on the research I came across on how to write a survey. The major points where the following , but there will be more at a later point.
  1. Objectives. Focus on the topic you want answers to. If there lots of decisions then maybe have two surveys instead of one long confusing survey
  2. Work Backwards. Once you've set your objectives, determine the information you need to get in your survey to make your decision
  3. Bias. Make sure you're not asking leading questions or pre setting there mind.
  4. Review and get feedback. Send your survey to some friends for a test run. They'll help make sure your questions and response options are understandable and all your survey just works.
  5. Make it quick and easy to do !!!!!

item.title: Robert's Research: Bag Tracking App
item.dc:creator: robertgabriel2015
item.content:encoded: After our talk today with Phil, we felt it was best to pick 3 other ideas and research them, to fourth develop our idea and improve it in a way. if it was already existing.I picked the Bag Tracking App to research. SuperSmartTag SuperSmartTags feature a code that anyone can use to report your bag online. Once the code for your bag is submitted, you'll receive a text message, email or phone call explaining that your luggage has been found. Enter your itinerary on the SuperSmartTag site and airport staff will be able to view your travel plans and forward your luggage to your next destination. SuperSmartTag retails for $19.95 AUD (about 18.59 USD as of this posting) and comes with a three-year membership to the SuperSmartTag system. Fly Delta App This App already made by the juggernaut that is delta was our idea. Delta passengers can download a free smartphone app that features, among other things, a way to track your bags, even while in flight. Just enter the number on your bag receipt -- or scan with the barcode with your phone -- and you can follow your luggage from departure to arrival. The app is available for iPhone, Windows Phone, Android and BlackBerry. TLDR: This idea is already there, no need to rub the salt into our cut :'(

Hopefully you will enjoy as we discover and make some innovate ideas.

item.title: Brain Storming Ideas
item.dc:creator: robertgabriel2015
item.content:encoded:
Today in class, we started brain storming different ideas and problems that we all have (so that we could then think of a digital solution), using the methods which Phil had taught us, namely writing down the problem, and then moving onto thinking of another problem or idea to write down. At the end of the exercise, we review all the ideas and this prevents us from focusing on any one idea to the exclusion of other possible good ideas.

Some of them were the following

  1. Wifi Finder
  2. Class room finder
  3. Iwatch (smart watch) vibrates when you go away from the phone.
  4. Calendar + notes taking app.
  5. Wheres my bag, finding your lost bag. Example at an airport from your phone.
  6. Free parking spaces.
  7. A working where's my bus app.
  8. Slow internet speeds.
  9. What labs have what software.
  10. Improved phone battery
  11. Cv builder.
  12. Mood improver app.
  13. Traffic
  14. Blackboard Improvement/Alternative
  15. Better Hurley Grips
  16. Petrol Station Opening times?
  17. Parking disc system in Cork City is awful for people at work!
  18. An app not necessarily for monetary gain but to increase environmental awareness on campus, a credit incentive for staff and students alike.
As you can see if your reading this, these are problems everyone faces.

item.title: Chosen Problem and How we can Solve it!
item.dc:creator: peterbohane
item.content:encoded:
Over the weekend we discussed our options and decided upon which problem best needed solving. There are plenty of timetable apps, and also some note taking apps on the Google and Apple app stores, but there are none which properly merge these two. Our idea is to create an app which will keep record of your class timetable, alert you when you have an upcoming class, and allow you to takes notes on the class right within the same app. As the app knows which class you are in, it will automatically store the note under that class' notes (E.G. 'Interdisciplinary, 3PM 4/10/2015'). This solves a number of problems including but not limited to:
  1. Note Organisation
  2. Class Attendance
  3. Productivity
  4. Time Management
  5. Project Planning

item.title: Class: Monday October 5th
item.dc:creator: peterbohane
item.content:encoded: We discussed our ideas with Phil and went through our logs on this blog. We informed him that we had decided on going with the Timetable and Notes taking app, but he thought that we should research a few more of our ideas. We researched the Notes App, Luggage Tracker and (Bries chosen app). The results of this research will be logged above! At this stage we are aiming to have our problem and solution decided by Wednesday 7th, at which point we can begin working on our 5-slide presentation for next Wednesday Oct 14th.

item.title: Peter's Research: Timetable and Notes App
item.dc:creator: peterbohane
item.content:encoded:
My main objective with this research was to find out about stuff. More specifically; if there were any other pre-existing apps out there doing this, or what/who our main competitors would be. iStudiezPro - Apple Keeps track of your timetable, deadlines, grades and more across all Mac devices — all you need to do is plug your class schedule into the app. It comes with both Cloud syncing and iCal integration. Problems:
  • iPhone Only
  • Cant take Notes
  • costs 2.99
  • Interface is old
Class Timetable - Apple & Google Play   Class Timetable is the perfect companion for school, college or university. Keep track of classes and add events to your week's schedule with ease. It has a really nice, simple interface and you can add tasks and assignments. Problems:
  • Cant add notes
  • Limited info on class (e.g.Cant add Room Number or Lecturer)
Timetable - Google Play Timetable is the most beautiful and intuitive app on Google Play for managing your school or university life. Save your timetable and all tasks from homework to exams. You only need to enter them once, because Timetable syncs across all your Android devices. Often forget to turn down your phones volume? No problem the app automatically mutes your phone during lessons. Problems:
  • Cant Add Notes
  • Intuitive Interface, Could be improved.
Timetable++ Schedule - Google Play TimeTable++ - The schedule for school, university and free time! Features: ✔ Full calendar - but easy to use! ✔ Homework, notes, notifications ✔ Exams and marks ✔ Pictures and audio recordings ✔ Cancellations and free days ✔ Device muting during lessons ✔ Countdown to next lesson ✔ Share your timetable with your friends! ✔ Unlimited number of timetables ✔ A lot of different widgets ✔ iCalendar support
So this is what I identified as most similar to our idea, and in some areas it has surpassed our ideas! I have downloaded and used this app and found a few flaws:
Problems:
  • Intuitive Interface but could do with visual improvements!
  • Notes can not be uploaded to computer (e.g. link with dropbox would be great)
  • Its a free app with ads, but the ads can not be removed! In our app I would imagine a lite (limited features) and a paid app (all features available)

item.title: Brie's Exploration of Recycling Apps
item.dc:creator: maturebrie
item.content:encoded: My main objective for this research was to see if there were any already existing apps that involve recycling. During my exploration of this I came across 3 apps that promote recycling. iRecycle - Developed by Earth911, iRecycle is the premiere application for finding local, convenient recycling opportunities when you are on the go or at home. iRecycle is free and provides access to more than 1,600,000 ways to recycle over 350 materials. Download iRecycle for your iPhone or Andrioid. Pros - free app. Easy to use layout. Cons - (USA only) information only relevant to USA, current app takes up a lot of storage. 1800Recycling - Developed by Electronic Recyclers International. 1800Recycling.com app helps you quickly find recycling locations nearest you. This free app is the easiest way to find convenient drop-off locations and organize your recyclables quickly and effectively. You can even share and rate your recycling experiences to help others recycle better! This app makes it easy to go green. Pros - Uses GPS and interactive maps, free app. Cons - app not available outside of USA. Recyclebank - Recyclebank rewards members for recycling. They make it easy to find out what and how to recycle, and reward you for keeping those materials out of landfills. This app allows you to track your progress and see how many points you have earned, giving you access to a catalog of items you can redeem your points on. It will also remind you of your recycling/bin collection dates. Cons - poor software configuration, app in general doesn't seem to work for the past couple of months, USA only. Pros - Modern layout, free app. The closest app I found in regards to an Irish recycling app was, Wiser Recyclings' (based in Cobh & Midleton) customer service smart phone app called Household. Household reminders you of your next collection and can facilitate you paying for your services via the app. Cons - it doesn't offer information on items to recycle and locations of other various recycling areas. From my research it appears there isn't yet a solid Irish solution for recycling available, it could be something worth looking into and pursuing further.

item.title: Presentation - Monday October 12th
item.dc:creator: maturebrie
item.content:encoded:
Over the weekend we used Google Docs to work on the presention together.
Before the presentation class, our group met up to revise what slides we had prepared and discuss who would present what material to the class. It was a very productive session and we worked well within the timeframe we gave ourselves. We went over our project proposal too to get a firm grip on the direction we want to take our app before we proceed any further.
After the presentation Phil and Lisa gave us feedback. They thought our presentation focused too much on our research and not enough on our app idea :(. In general we need to work on our presentation but our idea is good and merits more work being put in :).

item.title: Research Material Design vs IOS Design Langues
item.dc:creator: robertgabriel2015
item.content:encoded:
When designing or starting a project for mobile it is important to stay with a design langue. For people who don't know a design langue "A design language or design vocabulary is an overarching scheme or style that guides the design of a complement of products or architectural settings." The major ones that are over the web that you may or may not know are Material Design and IOS Design. Us as the group (picked material design) and I as an induival researched the use of these.
  • Speed
  • Readability
  • Bold, graphic, intentional
  • Material is the metaphor
  • Motion provides meaning
  • Use of color is the same
  • Battery Program.
  • Font is readable on different colors
We picked Material design as it is designed and well suited for Desktop and Mobile apps, helps with people who are visual impaired while also taking into account HCI elements of how long it takes for a menu to open etc. Where Ios is best looking on apple devices but not on the overall screens. Such as normal un-high-tech screens and machines

item.title: Development of app layout & features.. more to follow
item.dc:creator: maturebrie

item.title: Research : Freemium vs Premium Models
item.dc:creator: robertgabriel2015
item.content:encoded:
After spending some time researching, there are three dominant pricing strategies in the app market as we know it: Premium, Subscription and Freemium. According to a report by Distimo and Saas anuilual report freemium now accounts for 78% of Apple AppStore revenues in the US and Europe, up from somewhere around 59% last year, and rising. Premium apps have an a once off price before they can even be downloaded to the machine. The App Store makes all future upgrades to the premium app free once purchased. Freemium, is where the app is free to download and use. Some features inside the app are blocked until you pay for them. This is super popular as stated above. A shocking turn of events, Subscriptions are sometimes a better and newer way make money off your app. Subscriptions are a regular fixed fee the user is charged automatically via the App Store for using the app, kinda like time magazine or Playboy. Subscriptions can actually overlap with either freemium models. For example, Apple Beats is close to freemium where you can pay a subscription to get ad-free and unlimited hours of music, best of both worlds. In general, premium works in the following situations:

1. There is a strong demand for your app.

2. You have a strong brand already and can establish trust with users where they are willing to pay before they download the app.

3. Word of mouth and being the top of the app store.

Freemium helped create those million dollars per-day  bsusiness for a few months, but writing about catching that genie in the bottle, there is no proof or forum to make that work. Then as spoken about earlier the subscription provides a guarantee of repeat transactions and hence, businesses with subscription revenues tend to be valued far higher. The subscription price is usually smaller than the one-time price to incentivize the user into a longer term commitment.

item.title: Early Design Development
item.dc:creator: peterbohane
item.content:encoded:
I worked on designing some of the main pages of the Android App. I based the design on Google's Material Design. The idea of the Dashboard is to display the:
  • Current Active Class
  • Next Scheduled Class
  • Overview of Todays Classes
  • Overview of all Upcoming Assignments and Exams.
This is the first screen that will load up when you open the app, so the user can gain a lot of information without needing to open multiple pages within the app. I also designed what the menu will look like when you open it. Here you can see the main features/options of the App:
  • Dashboard
  • Timetable (Dayview, Weekview, Mixed View)
  • Notes
  • Tasks (Assignments and Exams)
  • Share (Upload to Cloud)
  • Settings
I plan to design the Weekview Timetable and the Notes pages next

item.title: R and D Presentation
item.dc:creator: maturebrie
item.content:encoded: This afternoons presentation went well. We got some critical feedback to help our presentation and research develop further; Less text and larger fonts, pay attention to the order of the slides and stay true to the title of the slide. In regards to research we need to dive in further, with primary and secondary studies. Primary - First hand research; Target audience, Focus groups, surveys ect. Secondary - Information already available, its just a case of finding it. The thing we need to remember that research is constantly ongoing and can influence the outcome or the development of our app. We have also begun prototyping designs and playing around with the layouts of our app -> photos to be uploaded shortly!

item.title: The Cloud & Sharing - A Brief Description
item.dc:creator: peterbohane
item.content:encoded: The idea of The Cloud & Sharing came to us out of nowhere, but we instantly realised it's importance to our idea. The Cloud will allow you to upload notes and timetables to our server, From there you can access these notes and timetables from various platforms (IE Android Devices, Apple Devices, Live Website). To use the cloud you will have to create an account with us (A little like Dropbox). On this account you can add friends, and grant these friends access to your notes and timetables. This is where sharing is key. It will allow people to share notes and timetables with ease. As an added bonus, it will encourage people to tell others about this app, and hopefully cause a word-of-mouth snowball effect.

item.title: Usability & Interface design
item.dc:creator: maturebrie
item.content:encoded: Todays class was predominately aimed towards generating prototypes to test the usability of our interfaces and design layout on a 'skeletal level'. Robert is developing a live prototype based on my current design.

item.title: Survey Questions
item.dc:creator: robertgabriel2015
item.content:encoded:
After many hours and meetings, we can together with the following survey which allows us to get the information we need. Like the following, devices to support, platforms, features to add in the future and the pricing along with the target  market and areas of growth.

Name

 

Which age bracket do you fit into?

  • Less than 13
  • 13-18
  • 19-25
  • 26-35
  • 36-50
  • Over 50

What's your job title?

  • Unemployed
  • Part-time
  • Full-time
  • Self-employed
  • Student
  • Student & Working Full Time/Part Time

Do you own any of the following?

  • Android Phone
  • Iphone
  • Windows Phone
  • Other

What do you most use your phone for?

  • Text/Phone Call
  • Social Media
  • Messenger Apps
  • Gaming
  • Photography
  • Note taking
  • Watching Video Content (Netflix etc)
  • Other (please state)

Do you use your phone in class?

  • Yes, Every Class
  • Yes, Occasionally
  • Depends on The Class/Lecturer
  • No

What do you usually use to take notes in class?

  • Pen and Paper
  • Laptop
  • Phone

Which of the these methods do you think would be easiest to categorise, sort and access your notes?

  • Pen and Paper
  • Laptop
  • Phone

Which of these is most easily accessible to you throughout the day?

  • Phone
  • Laptop
  • Notepad & Pen

Do you ever find your school bag too full?

  • Yes
  • No
  • Sometimes

Do you ever forget the start/end times of your classes?

  • Yes
  • No
  • Sometimes

Are you ever late for classes, deadline or important meetings as a result of having the wrong time?

  • Yes
  • No

Would you share notes with friends more often is there was an easy way to do so?

  • Yes
  • No
  • Maybe

Do you use your phone's timetable/calendar application?

  • Yes
  • No

Do you use a notes app?

  • Yes
  • No

Would you use an app that integrated both taking notes and your class/work timetable?

  • Yes
  • No
  • Maybe

Do you use Cloud-based software/programs such as Dropbox, Google Drive or Skydrive?

  • Yes
  • No

Do you currently find it difficult or time consuming to transfer text files and documents from your phone to your PC/Laptop?

  • Yes
  • No

item.title: Class: Feedback on Business Plan
item.dc:creator: robertgabriel2015
item.content:encoded:
The past week, three of us worked on prototypes and design. We worked a very brief (24 hours) business model canvas. Today in class, Peter and myself (Rob) (bree was at work) sat down with Lisa and Phil who went through our business plan. We also looked at past business plans from the innovation week and got a great idea on the layout and how to format it. Some of the feedback included were the following
  • The name isn't great and confusing.
  • The over format needs great improvement.
  • That Peter should do the summary and Value areas as he has the most passion and vision for the product as he thought of it.
  • The research on Value was great but needs to be improved.
  • The finances were great but need to define a little better.
  • The budgeting we have for the first year and bootstrapping until it gets viral was good.
  • We need to following the headings (This is my mistake, as we followed a different template.)
  • Our Research needs to defined clearly.
  • Talk in the third person.
I (Rob) Updated the doc with the new layout, third person and fixed some of the above so we as a group can sit down and go through everything and use the business model canvas to think of different approaches. Google Docs File

item.title: Progress report..
item.dc:creator: maturebrie
item.content:encoded: ON mondays class, feedback was given in regards to my design prototypes, it was encouraged for me to explore more user interfaces and gather a small library of user features that I like from other relative apps. I have also been working on logos for our 'Notetracker' app too, to strengthen the brand we are trying to develop.

item.title: Survey Results
item.dc:creator: peterbohane
item.content:encoded:
In preparation for our presentation on Wednesday 18 November, we gathered all of our survey results and began analysing them. We had 86 responses to the survey,  and it turned up some really surprising results: Points to take from the results:
  • 33% of people already use a notes app
  • 80% of people forget class start times
  • 70% of people find their schoolbag too full
  • Only 40% think that Pen and Paper is the best way to organise notes
  • 90% of people already use their phone is class
  • 45% of people are late for classes/meeting as a result of having the wrong time
  • Only 17% said they would not share notes with friends

item.title: Final feedback
item.dc:creator: maturebrie
item.content:encoded:
Yesterdays presentation on Prototypes and Research was our last one before our final presentation. Our critical feedback from Phil & Lisa:
  • Our presentation seemed disjointed, we weren't speaking as a joint effort/team, we were all just saying our piece (it didn't flow or gel well).
  • Our slides were content/copy heavy and we could try to make it more visual as not to confuse our audience or distract them from what information we are presenting to them. Too much being said and too much copy equals to poor communication.
  • Any figures we show on in our presentation need to be backed up, we can't expect to shout off figures and not have an explanation for them.
  • Powerpoint presentation - the actual slides, need to be consistent with each other in regards to use and size of font and it is critical that we check our spelling too.
Taking this feedback on board will put us in good stead to give a great final presentation.

item.title: Research Insurance Costs
item.dc:creator: robertgabriel2015
item.content:encoded: While doing research into the different costs, Insurance was one of the ones that we had to take into account. So here is the different types of common insurances for startups General Liability Insurance General insurance system of risk financing to protect the purchaser (the "insured") from the risks of liabilities imposed by lawsuits and similar claims. Property Insurance. A policy that provides financial reimbursement to the owner or renter of a structure and its contents, in the event of damage or theft. Business Owner’s Policy. Insurance policies that combine protection from all major property and liability risks in one package Worker’s Compensation. Workers' compensation is a form of insurance providing wage replacement and medical benefits to employees injured in the course of employment in exchange for mandatory relinquishment of the employee's right to sue his or her employer for the tort of negligence. Professional Liability Insurance. Professional liability insurance is a specialty coverage that is not provided under homeowners' endorsements, in-home business policies or business owners' policies. It only covers claims made during the policy period. Data Breach. If the business stores sensitive or non-public information about employees or clients on their computers, servers or in paper files they are responsible for protecting that information. If a breach occurs either electronically or from a paper file a Data Breach policy will provide protection against the loss. It's clear to us for the use of the company and what it will be doing the Data breach. As with modern age of cloud and hacking for fun, We have to a high level of protection in cause information was to be hacked. We will have insurance to cover this. Laws vary from country to country, but this can be enough to qualify as “personally identifiable information” (“PII”), which you can be held liable for if disclosed accidentally or maliciously. The average yearly cost to cover and have data breach Insurance is Approximate pricing: 1500 per year. We will also need General Liability Insurance which is about Approximate pricing: €500-2,000 per year

item.title: Scrum
item.dc:creator: robertgabriel2015
